title: Artificial Intelligence for Europe: Strategy for ethical and trustworthy AI
segmentation: So my name is Rebecca.
I thank you very much.
I think the organizers for for this invitation.
I have only one regret is that I don't understand the Slovenian language, so I missed all the jokes.
I just understood blue screen or something but but it's yeah, maybe next time I'll be able to get also that part.
So the transition with Emily, I think is is relatively easy.
She has already set the stage.
She has also presented the the second scenario.
Which is the top scenario and which happens to be our scenario.
So I think this is very encouraging.
So I will try to in 20 to 22 minutes.
Try to give you an overview of what we do at European level today on AI and trustworthy.

I so this is the this is the main objective in Europe AI systems that will be sold that will be implemented that will be used in Europe should be trustworthy and I think Emily also came to the trust dimension in your presentation.

I of course Emily gave a very clear picture.

Big hopes.

A very important development for our future for our economy.

the French minister for Economy and he talked about AI being an existential question.

We have a big challenge.
In Europe we are still not very far from the level we should be at in order to compare to what China with the US is investing.
So there is there is a lot to do and this is actually.
The one of the main.
Thrust.
Of what we're doing.
So we need to play on our strength.
We have some strength.
We have a lot of strength in industrial technology.
For examples.
Of course in robotics, industrial robotics in particular, in in automotive in computing.
So we need to make sure that we develop this on the strength we digitize, 'cause this is also something that was mentioned this morning.
I think one way to look at AI is just to say this is the next step of digitalization of our society and industry.

So it's about using better use of data, better use of computing capabilities to move to the next stage of digitization, so perhaps there is also a bit of misunderstanding and hype about what they are is.
So we need to play to our strengths and.
In the in the next Commission and in the in the coming years, we are proposing to strongly increase our investment and this would correspond to the two Emily second scenario.
We have already started to increase their investment in research and innovation in 1820 where we are increasing by 70% what we allocate to AI.
And I ultimately what we would like to to get to is about 20 billion investment per year.
After a little bit from 2021.
So we are increasing strongly.
This is at the moment a proposal, and that's where we need also the support of each of the Member States too.

Make sure that we pass this proposal and are able to finance AI from the Commission support side as much as we need to in order to bring in more investment or attract more investment from Member States from industry.
So in the next Commission we will see I apologize for some of these.
This cryptic acronyms here, but we will see a number of big initiatives that will continue some of the current initiatives.
There will be some new ones on these areas where we believe we need to have technological sovereignty, so this includes high performance computing.
This includes quantum.
This includes, of course, cyber security and AI, blockchain etc.
So with all these different tools.
Detail your program.
The EP that's a new program that we are proposing 9 billion over seven years.
Not agreed yet, so there's still some work to do, but we hope it will be.
It will pass with connecting your facility with the investor you with Verizon Europe, which is which is proposed to be the largest.
Program with 100 billion euro and with other all the tools we want to to push this technology.
Technological capability of Europe.
In terms of AI, so we have this strategy that we launched last year in 2018 in April, which is a strategy three parts.
So the first part is AI uptake and research and investment.
Second parties prepare for the changes.
So as was said earlier, alot of grey zones on the impact of AI on the economy, but we need to be prepared for that.
Skills education is a big part, but not only.
And then, of course, the ethical and legal framework.
So I'll come to this later.
So in this, in this context we have created or we have put together this high level expert group that has been functioning since June 2000.
18 So I'll come back to that.
So what we are putting in place is a strategy on infrastructure.
So that's high performance computing.
That's a large scale testing facilities.

So these are still opportunities.

For this.
You might be a bit late for registering, but if you if you ask kindly, they might let you in, so this will be on the 26th of November, so that's for the part on research.
For the.
Future, as I said, we have proposed quite ambitious programs.
One is digital Europe with the part on the eye with what we propose is 2.5 billion over 7 years.
For AI within this program, and of course within the horizon Europe which we are proposing to be 100 billion.
We're not there yet, but we hope will get that and within that we will have a number of activities.
Of course, on next generation AI unexplainable AI but also on using AI.
Exploiting your in a number of areas.
So just a little zoom on the detailed program because it'll your program, because that's a new program that we are.
We hope we will be able to launch.
As I said, AI 2.5 billions cybersecurity 2.
In the digital transformation, so applications 1.3 billion high performance Computing 2.7 and 700 million on skills.
This is what we propose for the next step.
News so one way to do that I like to use to illustrate what we want to do in the Jelly or program with respect to hubs and bringing this technology to the users into the SMS.
Is this notion of having in Europe top capacities in AI for example, so testing, testing facilities, data pools, etc bringing them through the different hubs anywhere in Europe too?
So you could be in a very remote region.
And you would still have access to the HPC capacity or to the high capacity that we would be funding.
So this would be a condition for us to fund these things.
Is this openness and this availability of the of the resources so they can be shared.
They can be used.
So we have of course, in order to implement our strategy, we are working with Member States, so we have what we call a coordinated plan.
So we meet 3 * 3 four times a year with.
Member States representatives and their we discuss national strategies.
So there I think that's the next slide.
There are 14 Member states that have national strategies.
Today, 14 are in the making.
I think that's the case of Slovenia is still.
There is some discussion in order to finalize any strategy.
Here we discuss also a public private partnerships.
How can the Member States contribute?
To our activities, we discuss data spaces.
We discuss approaches to skills.
As you know, skills responsibilities more on the on the Member States, so we help there.
But the main action has to be on the Member State level.
And of course we discuss the trustworthy, the ethical part, the regulation part because that's very important as we as we know a number of Member States.
I've already started to propose things towards.
Regulation in the eye and this is 1 big motivation for us.
We don't want to have a multiplicity of rules in Europe, so that's also one reason why we need to move fast.
At European level.
So.
Sorry.
This is what this was, a slide that already mentioned 14 Member States.
Having already a strategy 14 working on one.
So on the on, the regulation on the framework for AI.
The result of the work of the of the high level group ethics guidelines.
They were published a few months ago.

With these ethics guidelines, we have some implementation rules if you like, and these are being tested now, there is a test phase or pilot phase that's running until the end of this month actually, and we have carried out a number like 50 or we called deep dives with all sorts of companies, including very big ones including non European ones.
And we have received input from I think about 500 organizations.
So these cover all these different.
Aspects of the guidelines so Human Agency oversight technical robustness safety privacy transparency.
Diversity, non discrimination.
So this is related to the previous discussion on bias.
Of course environmental well being and also accountability.
So these are the different dimensions that are in these guidelines and out of these pilot phase we will refine all the high level group will refine the guidelines and this will flow into the proper.
Mission of our proposal for regulation for AI at the later stage.
So this is the process that we are in.
We are around the very soon at the 1st of December at the end of the pilot phase, and then there will be the review of the guidelines.
So it's probably a bit late too.
Ask you to maybe look at these things and take part in the pilot, because that's not very realistic within two weeks.
But if some of you want to have a look, it might be still still interesting even if you cannot participate, proceed fully in the pilot.
So in this context, we have the new Commission and we're proud to have a new President elect who has put a lot of emphasis and also a lot of pressure on us to deliver something within 100 days.
So I can tell you life in the Commission, or at least in my Department, has changed drastically from that statement because we are now expected to produce something with our colleagues.
Of course, of the justice.
Did you grow because they are because AI is of course cross cutting, so we are working on something that will come out quite soon.
There will be a large consultation based on a lot of different ideas on how.
We could define a framework for AI.
All the the different dimensions that I mentioned here earlier on the on the the guidelines will be there.
Now of course we have.
I cannot tell you what the proposal will be.
I can only tell you that we have of course very large spectrum of options.
Whether we we regulate, you, know very softly, we just give some.
We use the guidelines.
For example, in order to encourage companies to follow these principles.
All the way to regulating more strongly and having clear obligations.
These are all different options that we need to weigh that will be discussed in this consultation that will come very soon early next year.
So in any case this was also when there were some questions about this earlier to Emily.
I think there is a sense of urgency and that's why we we have decided to move quickly.
And to hopefully be ahead of the curve.
AI is moving very fast, so this is the difficulty we have because on one hand we don't understand completely what needs to be done.
We don't always understand where AI is going.
On the other hand, we know we cannot wait because things are happening.
Things are coming on coming onto markets.
And and then we need to to have some kind of of way to to make sure that not too many mistakes are made at this stage.
So this is a difficulty we have.
This will be discussed in this big sorry consultation.
I'm sorry this big consultation that that will come and we hope that we will have your contribution.
Your input on this, so before closing I just wanted to give a couple of links to resources that we have, so that might be interesting to some of you.
Keep the platform European AI Alliance, which is which has a lot of resources and a lot of it is actually.
Administered, or how should I say the high level group contributes the people in the high level group contribute to discussion.
There are there are some reports.
There are some, some various resources on the eye, so I think this is something if you want to get up to speed on the eye.
In Europe this is 1 one source.
The other source is the iWatch platform, which is something we are.
We are now launching and we are working also together with you, a CD, to enhance it to cover more ground.
So it's about analysis about investment, about technology monitoring, etc.
So also an interesting resource if you want to get into the eye in Europe picture.
Two to conclude, I would like to broaden up a bit the discussion in terms of AI globally.
So as we see, this is something that has been updated recently.
These are all the different initiatives, strategies, etc that have been presented so clearly globally.
Here is very hot alot of countries.
Good defining strategies, but we also have a lot of international activities.
And I think I have them here.
We CD, for example, adopted there some some recommendations, some guidelines which are by the way very close to what Europe is doing over the European Union is doing.
There was some discussion on the last G7 in France on the eye with the creation of something called the Global Partnership on AI.
That's led by France and Canada.
There was in the G20, also the OECD.
The declaration of OECD recommendations led to a declaration within the G20.
There is UNESCO also working on this Council of Europe.
Lots of activities on standards, so we are following all this.
We're trying to contribute to all this.
We're trying to influence all this as well and to make sure that the the idea is developed in Europe are are represented there.
I think this is looking good because for example, the G20 declaration is actually based on the OECD which is close to what we are.
Which we are proposing.
So we we are at the moment promoting the participation of the third countries in our in our testing phase.
We have some bilateral dialogues with Japan with Canada, with Singapore with other countries that we consider our like minded countries and we will continue to push for this agenda.
So.

Oops, so to conclude, I think what we're proposing, what we have is is a digital policy mix and it's it's it's a mix between an investment strategy saying in Europe, we we can, we can compete, we can develop what we could see is 1/3 way as opposed to the the Chinese way, which would be a very top down way with a lot of investment.
A lot of control.

By by the state and as opposed to the US way, which is more based on openness maybe and large companies, we believe we need to have a third way in Europe which would be based on our on our core values and that's that's the that's the basis for these these guidelines.
And this regulation we are thinking about what we need to do is to give businesses clear uniform rules and to provide regulatory clarity.
And I think it's only like this that we will allow Europe to get benefit from these major opportunities that are brought by.
So thank you for your attention.
